Patient Note:
- The patient is a 45-year-old postmenopausal woman with cytologically confirmed breast cancer.
- A core biopsy revealed a 3 cm invasive ductal breast carcinoma in the left upper outer quadrant.
- The tumor is HER2-positive and ER/PR negative.
- Axillary sampling revealed 5 positive lymph nodes.
- CXR was remarkable for metastatic lesions.
- The patient is using multivitamins and iron supplements.
- She does not smoke or consume alcohol.
- She is not sexually active and has no children.
- She is a candidate for tumor resection and agrees to do so prior to chemotherapy.

Clinical Trial Inclusion Criteria:
- Women of any age with clinical stage II breast cancer
- Primary tumor less than or equal to 5 cm in size with axillary lymph nodes which are clinically ([N0 or N1] [T1N1, T2N0, T2N1])
- Histologic sections of the breast tumor must be classified as an invasive primary breast neoplasm of epithelial origin
- Estrogen receptor (ER) status can include ER positive, negative, or unknown
- Patients with prior cancers may be eligible as long as they have received curative therapy and have had no evidence of recurrence for greater than or equal to 10 years

Exclusion Criteria:
- Advanced local disease or distant metastases (stage III or IV)
- Previous therapy to the breast other than excisional biopsy
- Pregnancy
- Unwillingness to use birth control during chemotherapy
- Chronic disease such as heart, lung, liver, kidney, blood or metabolic disorders which may render the patient a poor risk for surgery or chemotherapy

Assessment of Eligibility:
The patient meets the inclusion criteria for the clinical trial:
- She has clinical stage II breast cancer with a primary tumor less than 5 cm and positive axillary lymph nodes.
- The tumor is an invasive ductal carcinoma, which meets the histologic criteria.
- Her ER status is negative, which is allowed.
- She has no prior history of cancer.

The transient elastography is a useful tool for early diagnosis of liver fibrosis. This tool is validated in the diagnosis of liver fibrosis due to C chronic hepatitis. Because it is non-invasive, fast, given immediate results; transient elastography could be repeated in alcoholic patients for liver fibrosis follow-up. In the present study, the investigators propose to realize liver biopsy and transient elastography in 300 alcoholic patients in weaning to evaluate the transient elastography accuracy in the exclusion of sever liver fibrosis (Metavir 3 and 4). The reference liver fibrosis diagnosis tool will be the liver biopsy.
